title-part.text: INDEXING SCHEME RELATING TO CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION TECHNOLOGIES RELATED TO BUILDINGS, e.g. INCLUDING HOUSING AND APPLIANCES OR RELATED END-USER APPLICATIONS

note.note-paragraph: Subclass Y02B and its groups are not complete

title-part.text: Integration of renewable energy sources in buildings
Uninterruptible or back-up power supplies integrating renewable energies
Energy saving technologies for incandescent lamps
for resonant dimming, e.g. by means of high frequency resonant bridges
Gas discharge lamps, e.g. fluorescent lamps, high intensity discharge lamps [HID] or molecular radiators
Mechanical details of compact fluorescent lamps
High pressure [UHP] or high intensity discharge lamps [HID]
providing detection and prevention of anomalous lamp operating conditions
Semiconductor lamps, e.g. solid state lamps [SSL] light emitting diodes [LED] or organic LED [OLED]
for driving the LEDs directly from an AC voltage source, e.g. with only passive components
Organic LEDs, i.e. OLEDs for general illumination
based on timing means or schedule
based on detection of the user
based on detection of the illumination level
Energy efficient heating, ventilation or air conditioning [HVAC]
relating to domestic heating, space heating or domestic hot water heating or supply systems [DHW]
Moistening the combustion air with condensate from the combustion gases
Modular boilers, i.e. connecting different sections within a boiler or cascading multiple boilers
Hot water central heating systems using heat pumps
Self contained heating units using heat pumps
combined with the use of heat accumulated in storage masses
Central heating systems having more than one heat source
Central heating systems using steam or condensate extracted or exhausted from steam engine plants
Domestic hot-water supply systems using recuperated or waste heat
Heat consumers: i.e. devices to provide the end user with heat
Low temperature radiators: i.e. convectors, radiators or a mixture of both with increased heat-exchange surface being suitable for systems working with a low temperature heat transfer medium
ceiling, wall or underfloor heating arrangements for being used in combination with water central heating system
Direct fired air heaters: i.e. the air being in direct contact with the exhaust gases of the burner

Heat recovery pumps, i.e. heat pump based systems or units able to transfer the thermal energy from one area of the premises or part of the facilities to a different one, improving the overall efficiency
Air based, e.g. mixed outside air and recirculation systems
Cooling using dew point control and direct humidifiers
Using energy from the ground by air circulation, e.g. "Canadian well"
Other technologies for heating or cooling
integrating combined heat and power generation [CHP] systems, i.e. trigeneration
Electric or electronic refrigerant flow control
Speed regulation of pumps in flow control systems
Speed regulation of fans in flow control systems
Speed regulation of fans and pumps in cooling towers
of heating or domestic hot water [DHW] systems
of refrigeration machines, plants or systems, including combined heating and refrigeration systems or heat-pumps
with air flow into the conditioned premises or facilities
Improving the thermodynamic properties of the premises or facilities
Technologies aiming at improving the efficiency of home appliances
Control circuit or coil power supply
Control circuit or magnetron power supply
Load impedance matching, e.g. by acting upon phase or frequency
Motor speed control of compressors or fans
Heat recovery e.g. of washing water
Optimisation of water quantity, e.g. of hot water
Motor speed control of drum or pumps
Heat recovery, e.g. of washing water
Motor speed control of drum or fans
Motor speed or motor power consumption control
Energy efficient batteries, ultracapacitors, supercapacitors or double-layer capacitors charging or discharging systems or methods specially adapted for portable applications
Energy efficient technologies in elevators, escalators and moving walkways
by delivering current to the grid for hydraulic elevators
Information and communication technologies [ICT] aiming at the reduction of own energy use
Reducing energy-consumption at the single machine level, e.g. processors, personal computers, peripherals, power supply
acting upon the main processing unit
Access, addressing or allocation within memory systems or architectures, e.g. to reduce power consumption or heat production, or to increase battery life
Interconnection, or transfer of information or other signals between, memories, peripherals or central processing units
the peripheral being a memory control unit [MCU]
the peripheral being disc or storage devices
The peripheral being a CD-ROM unit
the peripheral being a cursor control device
the peripheral being a PCMCIA card
Cooling means for computing equipment provided with thermal management
Power strips aiming to energy efficient operation
Reducing energy-consumption by means of multiprocessor or multiprocessing based techniques, other than acting upon the power supply
Increasing resource utilisation, e.g. virtualisation, consolidation
Reducing energy consumption at software or application level
At application level, i.e. feedback, prediction, usage patterns
Suspending or hibernating, performance or eco-modes, operating system support, e.g. advanced configuration and power interface [ACPI]
Techniques for reducing energy-consumption in wire-line communication networks
using reduced link rate, e.g. adaptive link rate, not involving auto-negotiation
by selective link activation in bundled links
by operating in low-power or sleep mode
specifically suitable for Ethernet, e.g. IEEE802.3az
High level techniques for reducing energy-consumption in communication networks
by proxying, i.e. delegating network functionalities while in low-power mode, e.g. ECMA 393 standard
by signaling and coordination, e.g. signaling reduction, link layer discovery protocol [LLDP], control policies, green TCP
specifically suitable for Ethernet, e.g. IEEE802.3az
Application modification for reducing energy-consumption, e.g. green peer-to-peer,
Techniques for reducing energy-consumption in wireless communication networks
Technologies for an efficient end-user side electric power management and consumption
Technologies improving the efficiency by using switched-mode power supplies [SMPS], i.e. efficient power electronics conversion
Power factor correction technologies for power supplies
Reduction of losses in power supplies
Low frequency active rectification, i.e. from a low frequency AC grid or generator
Converters benefiting from a resonance, e.g. resonant or quasi-resonant converters
by using wide band gap based power semiconductors, i.e. power converters integrating silicon carbide [SiC], gallium nitride [GaN], gallium arsenide [GaAs] or diamond power switches

Other technologies for reduction of losses, e.g. non-dissipative snubbers, diode reverse recovery losses minimisation, zero voltage switching [ZVS], zero current switching [ZCS] or soft switching converters
Efficient standby or energy saving modes, e.g. detecting absence of load or auto-off

Systems integrating technologies related to power network operation and communication or information technologies for improving the carbon footprint of the management of residential or tertiary loads, i.e. smart grids as climate change mitigation technology in the buildings sector, including also the last stages of power distribution and the control, monitoring or operating management systems at local level

reference.text: smart grids supporting the management or operation of end-user stationary applications in general, including technologies with no associated climate change mitigation effect Y04S20/00

title-part.text: characterised by the aim of the control
Demand response systems, e.g. load shedding, peak shaving
The system entering an energy saving mode, i.e. sleep, low-power or standby modes
The end-user application being or involving home appliances
The home appliances being or involving heating ventilating or air conditioning [HVAC] units
The system involving the remote operation of lamps or lighting equipment
The end-user application involving uninterruptible power supply [UPS] systems or standby or emergency generators

reference.text: for uninterruptible power supply systems or standby or emergency generators in the last power distribution stages Y04S20/12

title-part.text: Smart metering supporting the carbon neutral operation of end-user applications in buildings
Systems which determine the environmental impact of user behavior
Systems which monitor the performance of renewable electricity generating systems, e.g. of solar panels
Architectural or constructional elements improving the thermal performance of buildings
Wooden or plastic frames with extra insulation
Roof coverings with high solar reflectance
Floors specially adapted for storing heat or cold
Light dependent control systems for sun shading
Enabling technologies or technologies with a potential or indirect contribution to GHG emissions mitigation
Applications of fuel cells in buildings
Cogeneration of electricity with other electric generators
Emergency, uninterruptible or back-up power supplies integrating fuel cells
Cogeneration or combined heat and power generation, e.g. for domestic hot water
Fuel cells specially adapted to portable applications, e.g. mobile phone, laptop

Systems integrating technologies related to power network operation and communication or information technologies mediating in the improvement of the carbon footprint of the management of residential or tertiary loads, i.e. smart grids as enabling technology in buildings sector

reference.text: Smart grids supporting the management or operation of end-user stationary applications in general, including technologies with no associated climate change mitigation effect Y04S20/00

title-part.text: Systems characterised by the monitored, controlled or operated end-user elements or equipments
the elements or equipments being or involving energy storage units, uninterruptible power supply [UPS] systems or standby or emergency generators involved in the last power distribution stages

reference.text: energy storage units involved in power generation, transmissionor distribution Y04S10/14 ; uninterruptible power supply systems or standby or emergency generators as end-user application Y04S20/248

title-part.text: the elements or equipments being or involving protection elements, switches, relays or circuit breakers
the elements or equipments being or involving power plugs, sockets, adapters or power strips
the element or elements being a direct current power network, grid or distribution line
Smart metering mediating in the carbon neutral operation of end-user applications in buildings
the remote reading system including mechanisms for turning on/off the supply
Displaying of usage with respect to time, e.g. monitoring evolution of usage, relating usage to weather conditions
Utility meters which are networked together, e.g. within a single building
Systems oriented to metering of generated energy or power
Details of the transmission structure or support between the monitoring, controlling or managing units and monitored, controlled or operated electrical equipment
using the power network as support for the transmission
using modification of a parameter of the network power signal
Aspects related to the treatment or conditioning of data or signals
associated with communication via dedicated transmission supports
associated with communication via the power transmission network
